content:
The Soviet Union took several steps to try to end the Great Famine in the early 1930s, although the exact impact of these measures is still debated among historians.

One of the most significant steps taken by the Soviet government was the introduction of a system of food rationing, which was intended to ensure that the population had access to basic foodstuffs. The government also implemented a number of measures aimed at boosting agricultural production, including the construction of new irrigation systems and the introduction of more efficient agricultural techniques.

In addition to these measures, the Soviet government also made efforts to address some of the underlying causes of the famine. For example, it reduced the grain exports that had been a key driver of the crisis, and it began to take steps to improve the distribution of food and other resources within the country.

There were also a number of external factors that contributed to the end of the famine, including better weather conditions and improvements in agricultural technology and management.

Overall, while the Soviet Union did take steps to try to end the Great Famine, the crisis had a profound impact on the country and its people. Millions of people died from hunger and malnutrition during this period, and the crisis had significant social and political consequences within the Soviet Union.
